If you learn "AI" (machine learning, etc) you will discover that there is nothing Intelligent with "AI", and that's it's very over-hyped. You can "teach" a machine that 1+1=2 and 2+1=3 but if you ask it what 2+2 is it will have no idea. You can train a machine with one million pictures of dogs and cats, then show it a picture of a whale and it will say with 99% certainly that it's a dog. eg. it will only be useful in what it's trained for. Computers are fast, but they are also very dumb.

I'm a little concerned by some of the statements in this video, that were not entirely correct. I hope that this will not be a big concern for the actual course.
It's a cool topic though and I think that it's great that you will include some actual coding.

*Machine learning is not inspired by the human brain. Neural networks are (which is just a small part of machine learning).
** The field of AI is not really new at all. It's about as old as the electric computer, but have gained a lot of traction in the latest decade, as computer power has made it much more practical.

There's something that many (unfortunately not all, but what can you do) tech presenters have learned that I'll recommend to you. Try not to say the default activation words of the various assistants (Ok/Hey Google, Hey Siri, or Alexa) on video.
